verses.text: When the Sabbath was over, Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought spices, so that they might go and anoint him.
verses.comment: The women coming to anoint Jesus shows devotion and love even after his death. The use of spices was traditional for burial in Judea (John 19:39).

verses.text: Very early on the first day of the week, just after sunrise, they went to the tomb.
verses.comment: The resurrection happening on the first day of the week underlines its foundational importance for Christian worship practices, later observed on Sunday.

verses.text: They were asking each other, 'Who will roll away the stone from the entrance of the tomb for us?'
verses.comment: The stone blocking the tomb was heavy, symbolizing human limitation before the power of God revealed in the resurrection.

verses.text: When they looked up, they saw the stone had been rolled away, even though it was very large.
verses.comment: God's intervention is seen in the removal of the stone, showing His power over physical barriers, paralleling the removal of death's obstacle (Isa. 25:8).

verses.text: Entering the tomb, they saw a young man sitting on the right, dressed in a white robe, and they were alarmed.
verses.comment: The 'young man in white' is understood as an angelic messenger, representing purity and divine revelation (Dan. 10:5–6).

verses.text: But he said to them, 'Do not be afraid. You are looking for Jesus of Nazareth, who was crucified. He has risen. He is not here. See the place where they laid him.'
verses.comment: The declaration 'He has risen' is central to Christian faith, confirming Christ's victory over death. His resurrection fulfills prophecy (Ps. 16:10; Isa. 53:10–12; Acts 2:31), affirming Jesus' divinity and power.

verses.text: 'But go, tell his disciples and Peter that he is going ahead of you to Galilee. There you will see him, just as he told you.'
verses.comment: Peter is singled out, hinting at special restoration and leadership. Jesus' prior prediction (Mark 14:28) is about to be fulfilled, emphasizing his foreknowledge and authority. The restoration of Peter also hints at the importance of apostolic leadership.

verses.text: They went out and fled from the tomb, trembling and astonished. They said nothing to anyone, because they were afraid.
verses.comment: Their fear and reverence reflect the awe at God's power and the overwhelming nature of supernatural encounters.

verses.text: Now after he rose early on the first day of the week, he appeared first to Mary Magdalene, from whom he had cast out seven demons.
verses.comment: Jesus' first appearance is to Mary Magdalene, a woman previously healed, highlighting mercy and transformation. It also affirms the importance of female witnesses in divine revelation.

verses.text: She went and told those who had been with him, who were mourning and weeping.
verses.comment: The disciples' sorrow is transformed by the resurrection news, mirroring how Christian hope is rooted in Christ's victory.

verses.text: But when they heard that he was alive and had been seen by her, they did not believe it.
verses.comment: Their disbelief reflects the natural skepticism toward resurrection, which is overcome by direct encounters with the risen Christ.

verses.text: After this, he appeared in a different form to two of them as they were walking into the country.
verses.comment: Jesus’ appearance 'in a different form' to the disciples on the road to Emmaus shows his glorified state and also the need for spiritual recognition, not merely physical sight.

verses.text: They went and told the rest, but they did not believe them either.
verses.comment: Repeated unbelief highlights the extraordinary nature of the resurrection and prepares for Christ’s definitive self-revelation to all his apostles.

verses.text: Later, he appeared to the eleven themselves as they were reclining at the table; he rebuked their unbelief and hardness of heart, because they had not believed those who saw him after he had risen.
verses.comment: Jesus’ rebuke challenges his disciples to move from doubt to faith. His physical appearance among them underscores his bodily resurrection, essential for Christian doctrine.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'Go into all the world and proclaim the gospel to all creation.'
verses.comment: This global commission founds the universal mission of Christ’s followers. 'All creation' points to all peoples, emphasizing mission and evangelization rooted in apostolic authority.

verses.text: Whoever believes and is baptized will be saved, but whoever does not believe will be condemned.
verses.comment: A clear teaching that baptism is linked to salvation, not just belief. This points to the sacramental life as vital, with spiritual and literal implications for Christian practice.

verses.text: And these signs will accompany those who believe: In my name they will cast out demons; they will speak in new tongues;
verses.comment: Miraculous signs through believers are evidence of the continuing power and presence of Christ through the Church. Speaking in tongues and spiritual authority manifest the work of the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: They will pick up serpents with their hands, and if they drink something deadly, it will not harm them; they will lay hands on the sick, and they will recover.
verses.comment: These signs are not invitations to recklessness, but promises of divine protection and the healing ministry. The laying on of hands hints at a sacramental, communal practice continuing within the Church.

verses.text: After speaking to them, the Lord Jesus was taken up into heaven and sat at the right hand of God.
verses.comment: Jesus’ ascension and sitting at God’s right hand fulfills prophecy (Ps. 110:1), signifying divine kingship and intercession. The right hand is a place of authority and mediation, reflecting his continuing priestly ministry.

verses.text: And they went out and proclaimed everywhere, with the Lord working with them and confirming the message by accompanying signs.
verses.comment: The apostolic mission is dynamically ongoing, with the Lord working through his appointed messengers. The presence of signs affirms the authenticity and authority of their preaching. This highlights the continuing role of apostolic tradition and supernatural works within the Church.
